assumptions.text: Classical mechanics framework: relativistic effects negligible (v << c), quantum effects negligible for macroscopic bodies

symbol_definitions.definition: de Broglie wavelength of particles in the system
Characteristic length scale of the system

assumptions.text: Both bodies can be treated as point masses with spherically symmetric mass distributions
Observations are made from an inertial (non-accelerating) reference frame
Conservation laws (energy, momentum, angular momentum) hold for the system

symbol_definitions.definition: Total momentum vector of the system
Total angular momentum vector of the system

assumptions.text: System is sufficiently isolated from external influences (for gravitational systems: negligible external perturbations)
The spectral energy density `u(nu,T)` describes radiation from a perfect black body - an idealized emitter that absorbs all incident radiation and re-emits it purely based on temperature `T`
The radiation field is in thermal equilibrium at temperature `T`, meaning the emission and absorption rates are balanced and the energy distribution is time-independent
Electromagnetic waves have two independent polarization directions (transverse to propagation direction)
The speed of light in vacuum is constant and independent of the motion of the source or observer

symbol_definitions.definition: Speed of light in vacuum, exact value by definition in SI units.

assumptions.text: Reference frames move with constant relative velocity (no acceleration)

System describable by generalized coordinates `q_i(t)` with well-defined, twice-differentiable Lagrangian `L(q_i, dot q_i, t)`, smooth trajectories, and suitable boundary conditions for variational analysis (fixed endpoints, allowable interior variations)

symbol_definitions.definition: Generalized coordinates describing the system configuration
Time derivatives of generalized coordinates (generalized velocities)

assumptions.text: The system obeys the principle of stationary action (least action principle), meaning the path taken by the system makes the action stationary, leading to the Euler-Lagrange equations
Spacetime is flat, no gravitational effects considered
Particles have well-defined rest masses that do not depend on the reference frame
